bibl.title: Letter from Florence M. Read to Henry Rose Carter, July 21, 1921

div1.p: Read sends Carter the report of Hanson's work in Peru, which details water container inspections, quarantine, reported deaths and the training of more men.

div1.head: Letter from Florence M. Read to Henry Rose Carter, July 21, 1921

July 21, 1921
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter of July 20 has been received.
We shall be pleased to keep you in touch with the
development of the work in Peru. The letter Mr Rose
sent you today gives the latest information we have
from Doctor White. We have not heard from him since
he reached Peru.

A letter from Doctor Hanson received this
week contains the following information:

"It appears that our work in connection with
the cold weather will prevent a sharp epidemic in the city
of Trujillo. Our percentage of breeding there has been re-
duced to 4%, as calculated by the reports turned in by the
Inspectors and Domiciliary Visitors. This figure, however,
does not show the work actually done because lately Dr. Tapia
who is the Provincial Director had ordered that nothing but
barrels, botijas, tinajas, tanks and wells should figure as
a container or deposit examined. It happens that in Trujillo
there are many “corralones” i.e., a specie of departments or
flats, which have a common door or entrance from the street,
and in many of these we have from ten to twenty apartments,
in each of which there is a family. Since the campaign has
Doctor Henry R Carter
July 22, 1921
2.
been intensified all forms of containers with the ex-
ception of buckets and tin cans have been prohibited
in these apartments, with the result that the visitor
or inspector may visit as many as twenty families with-
out a single large “deposito” to figure in sum on which
the percentage is calculated. In Trujillo we do not
find larvae in these small containers, they are emptied
daily. In order to show the true percentage of foci of
breeding we will have to adopt a different basis for the
calculations and reports.

“In Libertad deaths have occurred in the follow-
ing places; - Pacanga, Pueblo Nuevo, Guadelupe, San Pedro,
Malabrigo, Paujan, Ascope, Casa Grande, and Trujillo.”

"In so far as the spread south is concerned, that
is the point which is causing me the greatest worry. Our
land quarantine seems to be of very small value....We have
relied on the desert of Viru, but even that is not a sure
guarantee. I have requested a double “cordon sanitario”,
one immediately south of the town of Viru, and another
guarding all the principal points of the boundry between
Libertad and Ancash.

“To have more assurance, I have engaged Dr.
Enrique Caballero, for special investigation of the coast
between Libertad and Callao. He is thoroughly reliable
and has the same opinions in this matter as I do.”

“In regard to Inspectors, I have taken every-
body available from the organization which Dr. Carter and I
had in Piura. In addition we have trained and are training
a great many in both Departments (Libertad and Lambayeque)
but the campaign is so immense that it takes time to get a
sufficient number of reliable men trained and located.”

"The present I consider the most critical period
of the campaign. The number of cases is everywhere di-
minishing, and as a result the people lose their fear and
have a tendency to grow careless thinking that it is all over.
At such a time we need the best help available until we have
passed the critical period, and can enter the prophylactic
Doctor Henry R Carter
July 22, 1921
3.
campaign proper, by this I mean the time when we are
fairly certain that we have had our last cases, and the
quarantine restrictions can be less rigorous. This I expect
to accomplish within the next three months, providing Dr.
Caballero does not find that something has escaped us farther
to the south. The whole thing depends on the latter observation;
if we are still safe on this point we will do the job this
year. The presence of Corrigan and Pickett will be needed
for about two to three months more to help assure this result.

"We are using all the fish available in all
sectors of the campaign. We have a fish here which they call
“majarra” which is a voracious larva consumer, I believe even
more so than the gambusia.

“We are using all means we can think of to combat
the larvae breeding.”
